title: The Great Score Strike
story_summary: Stenograd erupts as people scramble their BCI scores and erase records. Security forces crack down but lose control. The Council's new open-score system fails, turning order into chaos. Trust in the system collapses. Nobody knows what will replace it. The city waits in confusion and fear.

official.headline: Scores Under Review
official.anchor_line: Recent disruptions in the Behavioral Compliance Index, or BCI, have led to visible changes across neighborhoods.
official.contextual_reframing: The BCI is a citywide system scoring resident behavior for efficient services. Temporary disruptions are being expertly managed to ensure public order.

official.headline: Service Updates Ongoing
official.anchor_line: Citizens may notice temporary changes to access at jobs, housing, and checkpoints as BCI systems are optimized.
official.contextual_reframing: Automated governance ensures everyone's safety by continuously adapting to emerging challenges. Operational resilience remains strong.

official.headline: Transparent Progress Initiative
official.anchor_line: Council Innovators have introduced an open platform, letting all residents view and update their own BCI scores.
official.contextual_reframing: This pioneering approach strengthens trust and public engagement with city infrastructure, demonstrating the adaptability of technocratic leadership.

underground.headline: BCI Chaos Spreads
underground.anchor_line: People across Stenograd are erasing and scrambling their BCI scores, and the city's digital system can't keep up.
underground.contextual_reframing: The Behavioral Compliance Index, or BCI, was supposed to control everything from jobs to housing. Now it's losing grip. Officials said it was foolproof. Our neighborhoods are proving them wrong.

underground.headline: Checkpoints In Crisis
underground.anchor_line: Workplaces and services break down as fake and blank BCI scores jam every checkpoint.
underground.contextual_reframing: When your score controls your life, erasing it is power. State security scrambles to respond, but even their own ranks aren't immune. For once, lines blur between the monitored and those watching.

underground.headline: Council Loses The Reins
underground.anchor_line: The fancy new 'open score' platform lets anyone rewrite the BCI, turning trust into a joke for the Council.
underground.contextual_reframing: Innovators call it transparency. Most call it chaos. Stenograd's algorithmic masters have lost control, and the future is completely up for grabs.

questions.neutral: Did the city spit you out again?

hobby.message: Typewriters treating you better than people?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Seems so. City's loud today. Hard to keep old habits.
I restore typewriters. Not exactly popular now.
Can't find proper ribbons since the outages.
Everyone's guarding something, even ink.
You could say that. Feels like rules change every hour.
Spent the day with a Royal Quiet De Luxe. Precision keeps my mind clear.
Blackout made me pause. Ink smears if you rush.
People throw out old keys. I gather them, fix what I can.
Some things hold their value, even if the city forgets.
City's restless. Still, I keep to my routine.
I restore antique typewriters, actually. Bit of a lost art these days.
Keeps my hands steady and the noise outside my head.
During the last blackout, I switched to writing by hand.
Funny how power cuts draw people to my door, asking for paper.
Can't say it changes much. The words always find a way.
City never quite lets go, but there's comfort in old machines.
Spent half the morning coaxing a 1938 Underwood back to life.
Restoring typewriters, writing by hand... it's how I stay out of the fray.
The last blackout? Forced me to remember candlelight.
Some neighbors asked to borrow paper  -  happens more with BCI chaos.
It feels safer, typing my thoughts, than speaking them these days.
Strange, haven't shared that with many people lately.
Stenograd's always had a way of spitting people out gently. It's not new for me.
Restoring antique typewriters isn't just a pastime. It's a shield, in its own way.
Every time the power's out or the BCI falters, my Remington becomes priceless.
Last week, I hesitated to type names  -  felt exposed on the page for once.
Neighbors whisper more, borrow my ribbons, want advice on hiding words.
Before Halden's death, keeping a record was routine. Now it feels risky, almost defiant.
Paper and ink reveal more than they hide when trust collapses.
Suppose, for me, the hobby is survival  -  not just nostalgia anymore.
hobby_answer: Yes, typewriters. Simple things are best lately.
Haven't touched electronics in weeks. Safer that way.
Easier to keep memories steady on paper.
City's too loud for machines now, I suppose.
Paper doesn't erase itself just because a network dies.
Right, antique typewriters. Still working - when it's quiet.
Restoring a 1940s Olivetti last week, during the blackout.
Power cuts made it more... private than usual.
Strange feeling, writing while neighbors argue outside.
People are nervous. Paper seems risky now. Odd, isn't it?
Yes, typewriters and quiet suits me well these days.
Restored a Smith-Corona last Sunday in my flat.
Power blackout halfway through. Forced me to use daylight.
Kept the window open  -  easier to listen for trouble.
Heard some neighbors bickering over access lists.
Odd to think, but pen and paper feel almost subversive now.
BCI chaos made even handwriting suspicious in their eyes.
Exactly, antique typewriters and a quiet bar  -  comforts from simpler times.
Last week's blackout, must've been four hours, I worked by the window.
Couldn't use the lift. Whole building felt unsettled.
Typed out old Council minutes for myself, just habit.
Funny, paper felt riskier  -  so many are erasing things now.
Handwriting isn't anonymous anymore. Even that feels political lately.
BCI failures make little practices stand out in wrong ways.
Strange what counts as defiance now.
You're right, Alex. Bars like this remind me of my Council days  -  before all these algorithms.
I keep a 1938 Remington beside the bed, just in case.
Sunday, power went out again. Spent hours typing in the half-dark.
I heard voices in the halls, people checking doors. No one trusts who's allowed where anymore.
While I typed, I hesitated over which names to record. Even paper can incriminate, now.
After the Ledger leak, every small record carries weight.
Used to log Council routines for posterity. Now I barely trust myself to write dates.
Funny, in a city of erased scores, keeping words feels almost rebellious.
Guess that's why I still restore old typewriters. They won't betray what the network can't see.

main.opener: Folks don't always talk, but they carry plenty. You carrying much these days?
variants: Used to be I knew who came and went in my building. Now it's a guessing game.
Spent an hour waiting by the elevator. Routine's become rare.
I keep to myself more. Feels safer that way.
Let's just say, things aren't what they were.
They keep changing the access lists in my building. New faces, no explanation.
Elevators used to run on schedule, now just chaos. Saw a stranger try to follow me upstairs - claimed it was allowed.
Couldn't risk it. I waited, took the long way home. Locked up tight that night.
The rules seem to shift every hour. I trust paper more than screens.
Easier to avoid conversation these days.
Staying alert more lately. Saw my building's rules change three times in a day, nobody knows by whose hand.
Elevator's a lottery. A stranger wanted in, said he belonged - never seen him before.
I walked away, kept to the stairs. Can't trust the usual routine.
Checked policy updates twice as much as before. No one can give a straight answer now.
Stopped talking with neighbors much. My score dipped again. Not sure what that means anymore.
Feels like the ground's shifting under us.
When I retired, things made some sense - now the BCI's scoring is all noise. Last week, elevator logs meant nothing. Opportunists everywhere.
Had a run-in with some stranger in my own stairwell. He cited rules that don't exist. Familiar faces are fewer.
I waited him out, but it changes you. Came home more cautious, second-guessing every protocol.
Used to manage council routines. Now I watch boards flash conflicting lists, nowhere to turn for real guidance.
Can't even trust a nod in the hallway. Stopped checking messages unless I must. My score slipped. No explanation.
It's as if the order I used to believe in has turned its back on quiet lives like mine.
Everything is uncertain. Even trust feels rationed.
Old habits keep me careful, but they isolate me. Makes the silence in the apartment seem heavier.
Worked decades with the Council - knew the rhythms, trusted the order. Now I watch the system unravel in my own hallway.
Saw elevator permissions tossed around, faces I've never logged. A stranger wanted to follow, invoked phantom rules. I refused, circled the block before even going home.
They say the new open score platform will help, but I just see more confusion. Even my score fell - fewer nods, less talk, more logins.
My building was protocol on rails. Now it's a roulette. I lock up twice, ignore communal spaces. No comfort in manufactured transparency.
Council was always about order, not spectacle. The Harmonists meant to keep things running smoothly, quietly. Now even we're drowned out by noise from every side.
I still carry papers from before Halden died. They keep me grounded, but the weight grows. Feels pointless to check updates, but I do it out of habit - searching for any signal.
I steer clear of the neighborhood's panic. I chose caution, not because I'm afraid, but because I can't trust a process that's lost its guardians.
There's no map for this kind of uncertainty. Feels like the city's turned inside out. The quiet I once cherished is different - colder, harder to bear.
main.emotion: Feels isolated and unsettled, longing for familiar order.

emotional.opener: Nikola, it's perfectly normal to feel unsettled when the patterns change. Your experience matters, and you aren't forgotten in all this.
variants: I see you understand that not everything is straightforward now.
It helps to know someone notices.
Not everyone takes the trouble to say that.
I do appreciate some acknowledgment.
Perhaps that's rarer than I thought.
It's good to hear that from someone who isn't indifferent.
I suppose I miss when routines held meanings.
Things felt steadier then, more sensible.
We adapt, but it's something else to be seen.
You're right, the patterns always gave comfort, even if no one admits it.
Losing them... it's like losing the background hum of life.
I worked for people who insisted on order.
Sometimes old habits ache, but hearing this helps.
Thank you for saying that. Habit and routine were always my anchors.
Whole decades, I built my days on lists, approvals, well-laid timetables.
When patterns falter, it feels like the city forgets its own shape.
I remember a time when you could sense the Council's plan just by the morning announcements.
Now, some days I wonder what remains of it, or even of us, beneath the systems.
It's strange, but solidarity, even in small words, reminds me I am still myself.

factual.opener: Everyone's talking about the system falling apart - care to explain any of it?
variants: Reports of people wiping their BCI scores. Hard to know what's rumor these days.
Security's got their hands full. Been some clashes, they say.
The Council's not one for announcements lately.
Streets feel unsettled now. People testing limits, ignoring old routines.
If there's order left, it's not obvious.
Seems neighborhoods are playing games with their BCI records.
Rumor is Directorate tried to step in. Result was noise, outages, nothing fixed.
Council can't keep up. Systems are out of sync.
People who vanished from lists are surfacing again. Makes everyone jittery.
No sign of genuine control returning.
Not so simple as a technical glitch.
The 'Erase My Score' movement - sudden, messy, everywhere at once.
When the Directorate pushed back, they just fed the fire. Systems froze more than once.
Innovators tried that open score scheme. Just made everything meaningless.
Assignments, housing, even services - half of them broken because no one can trust the numbers.
Old network contacts started talking again, people I thought I'd never see.
Harmonists like me - what's left of us - shut out of the shouting. No appetite for spectacle.
It's a crisis built from silence and too many hands in the machine.
Order unraveled so quickly - score erasure was only the start. Now it's every neighborhood improvising.
Directorate's crackdowns stirred panic, they never really controlled the flows.
Saw faces in my building I haven't seen since before the disappearances.
I hear from old colleagues the Council lost their own protocols. Innovators made it worse with that open platform.
Housing assignments, jobs, permissions - all scrambling in the chaos.
A few of us who prefer quiet order have been pushed aside - Harmonists, forgotten in the din.
Personal papers and habits are all I trust now.
Feels like we're watching a city try to reinvent itself with no anchor.
I followed Council routines for years - trusted process, not improvisation. Now the whole city's in freefall.
People found ways to erase and scramble their scores. Suddenly rules vanished, and everyone started acting without fear of the system.
Directorate sent teams in, but the more they cracked down, the more citizens doubled down - network failures everywhere.
Innovators handed over the keys, let anyone edit a score, and it all collapsed into noise.
I recognized names reappearing in the system, people we erased or who vanished from our ledgers. Now they lead the new movements.
Most Harmonists have no place in these spectacles - quiet order's got no defenders left.
Those 'Ledger' rumors - about scores fixed for decades - are more true than they admit. I've read papers I should've destroyed.
Now the building's rules, housing, jobs - all just... suggestions. My own papers only weigh me down.
I retired for peace, not this kind of unraveling.

hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Out late with my drone tonight.
Had some trouble getting signal.
Everything's scrambled after today's chaos.
Just needed air.
Long. Flew my FPV drone again, even with all the noise.
Strange how signal keeps dropping now.
Hard to keep track of anything anymore.
Crowds make it worse, scrambling everything.
Still, beats being indoors.
Been flying my freestyle drone out by the ceramics plant.
Networks keep glitching - Erase My Score protests messed with the whole band tonight.
Lost telemetry and spent forever tracking it down.
Feels riskier every week, honestly.
Signal's just not reliable lately.
But it clears my head.
Yeah, it was...a night. I was out chasing my drone through broken kilns again.
FPV flying helps, even with all the digital chaos lately.
The comms blackout nearly cost me my drone tonight.
I used some old debug commands to find it - lucky, really.
People think these bands protect them but they just exposed all our habits.
Feels like nowhere's off-grid anymore.
I wouldn't trade the escape for anything, though.
Long one. Needed the drone run - I fly FPV freestyle to clear my head.
Ever since the BCI scores started getting erased, networks are a mess.
Tonight the mesh totally glitched. Lost contact and spent two hours hunting my quad.
Used a legacy circuit Marek Halden coded, actually - old devs left backdoors no one talks about.
Funny, the city thinks it can track us all but can't even patch its own rot.
People don't get how much time I spend in ruins just for a signal break.
The places I fly, most folks won't go. Too many band pings. Too much system jitter now.
But that's when it feels free, even if nothing is anymore.
hobby_answer: Yeah. I still fly when I can.
Not much signal lately, with all the network sweeps.
Too many people around these days. Makes it hard to focus.
Almost lost a drone last week - BCI outages, you know.
That's enough about it.
I do. Got a session in last Friday.
Had to stick to quieter zones. Crowd levels are unpredictable now.
BCI blackouts mess with telemetry. Not much control sometimes.
If you lose footage now, it's often gone.
Had to search in person for the drone. Not fun lately.
Still my thing, yeah. Drones are better than any therapist.
Factory ruins work best - fewer people, even now.
Last flight almost got trashed, BCI resets killed the autopilot.
I had to crawl under actual rebar to recover it.
All this 'Erase My Score' static swamped the band.
Flying used to mean escape. Now it feels like dodging another system failure.
Don't think anyone's escaping anything lately.
Definitely keeps me sane. Used to.
After hours in the lab, I need empty air and open halls.
Last week's chaos - BCI went haywire, drone fell out of the sky.
No mesh, manual recovery. Took forever. Skinned my hands up pretty good.
Local activists keep jamming the signal now - feels like flying through static.
People are angrier, crowding even the quiet spots, shouting about lost scores.
Missed when the only risk was bricking the drone.
Funny - the system's collapse shows up everywhere, even in the small stuff.
Yeah - FPV is still my escape, or tries to be.
Started because my brother got me into it. We built our first quad together.
Since he vanished, it's been my anchor. Now even that's getting complicated.
Last run, BCI collapses scrambled control channels. Drone fell behind a kiln, no tracking.
Spent hours crawling through scrap. Used old debug code, not the official mesh, to ping it.
Can't trust public spectrum. Everyone's scattering signal, Directorate is sweeping hard.
The 'Erase My Score' movement just ripped up the airwaves. Off-grid isn't off-grid now.
Miss seeing the world clean through goggles. It's all noise lately.
Systems are crashing, but maybe it's the only honest thing that's happened in years.

main.opener: Feels like there's a story behind that tone. You alright?
variants: Things at work have been different since the BCI went off-balance.
A lot of people came in, upset about their health band data.
My tasks changed, and records didn't match. It's all a mess now.
Honestly, I'm just tired of the confusion.
This week's got me out of sorts. People keep showing up, demanding their scores fixed.
We're told to ignore normal checks - just issue new bands based on what we hear.
I watched the system logs keeping score wrong, even on me.
It feels like no one's really in charge.
Can't say if it will settle down.
I spent the day reissuing health bands to people whose data all got scrambled after the BCI breach.
No one could prove who they were or what score they had, so we gave up checking.
They kept arguing over numbers, and my supervisor told us to just process whatever.
A few people I knew got help, but I avoided strangers - didn't trust what would happen to their records.
Afterward, my score dropped because of all the uncertainty. I felt every point.
It's been impossible to tell what matters anymore.
Honestly, everything's upside down. I used to keep people's data clean, but now, anyone can change their BCI score.
Crowds are desperate - some angry, some just lost. The lines outside the lab are endless.
We ditched all the strict protocols. Just handed out bands as people described themselves.
Records are getting tampered with by someone, maybe more than one group. I'm careful, only helping people I trust.
Lost track of tickets - my own score dropped hard, for no real reason.
It reminds me of when my brother disappeared. Back then, you just vanished if your data was wrong.
Now nobody's really safe, and I'm not sure if fixing anything matters.
Feels like there's nothing left of how things used to work. I was always good at hiding the little errors in people's data - helping out quietly.
When the BCI started failing last week, people who never questioned their scores are suddenly desperate, standing outside the lab, shouting.
Supervisors don't care about rules anymore - they just want the lines gone.
I hesitate every time someone new comes to my counter. You help, but the logs are being rewritten behind your back.
My own BCI score tumbled - fifty-four now. Can't close cases, can't trust the records.
Everything gets flagged. Maybe it's the Innovators' push for transparency, or just the old system falling apart.
I joined this work to make the system better after my brother vanished for a 'data mismatch'. But the more I do, the less it matters.
Right now, it just feels like survival. No one's guiding anything. I don't know if it'll ever settle.
main.emotion: Worn out, uncertain if things will ever go back to normal.

emotional.opener: You don't have to fix everything, Daria. You're not alone in this.
variants: Yeah. Maybe you're right.
It helps to hear that.
I guess I needed someone to say that.
It's hard to remember I'm not on my own sometimes.
Thanks.
That's actually a relief to hear.
I keep telling myself it's just a phase, but it doesn't always help.
Sometimes it feels like things never settle.
Your words make a difference.
Thank you for saying that.
I always feel like I have to be the one holding it together, even if that's impossible.
I forget there are good people left who see what we're all living through.
Some days, that's the only thing that gets me through.
It's good not to feel invisible.
Thank you, Alex. Honestly, I didn't realize how much I needed to hear that.
When everything keeps shifting, I start doubting if I fit anywhere.
Trying to keep up with expectations, adjusting, pretending it's fine - it's exhausting.
Most people act like none of this gets to them, but I know it does. We're all just hiding it.
Some days I feel hollow, like I've lost the thread of who I used to be before all this.
Hearing someone say I don't have to carry it alone... I can actually breathe for a moment.

factual.opener: Everyone's talking about these score erasures, crackdowns, even open scores - what's really going on?
variants: People are erasing their BCI scores now. Neighborhoods started it - everyone jumped in.
Saw more authorities come out, things got tense fast.
Heard the Innovators tried something with public scores, but it only spread chaos.
Feels like nothing is settled.
After those score erasures, whole areas stopped following BCI rules.
Authorities tried pushing back - doesn't look like it worked everywhere.
Now, anyone can pull up someone else's score or change it if they know how.
The system wasn't built for this much interference. Everything's frozen.
First, people figured out how to wipe their own scores, so full neighborhoods started dropping off the system.
Directorate sent in squads to reset order, but it just pushed the mess to other districts. Everyone's on edge.
The Innovators put out that open score platform, thinking transparency would help. Made things worse - people messed with everyone's scores for days.
No one at work knows whose data to trust. Assignments, housing, all in limbo now.
Most of the old rules are just broken.
If this is their idea of progress, it doesn't look like progress from where I'm standing.
All those score erasures kicked off unrest across whole neighborhoods. People coordinated wiping records, spreading it fast.
Authority crackdowns made things worse, sparked more resistance.
When the Innovators pushed for open scores, it was chaos. Literally, anyone with basic access tweaked the numbers - nobody trusted anything.
At the lab, service logs stalled out. Some folks just gave up trying to fix records at all.
Jobs and placements keep glitching. No official lists, just whoever shows up.
I was for more transparency, but this went too far and too fast.
The divisions on the Council are sharper than ever, especially with old Harmonists pushed out. Only Innovators and Directorate left shouting.
I've kept up with the block networks - after score erasures started, even people not usually involved joined in. Quiet coordination everywhere.
The Directorate's crackdowns were rough. Some old friends got caught, but that didn't stop anyone. People just got smarter about hiding changes.
When the open score test rolled out, it was supposed to build trust. Instead, it wiped out whatever was left. At work, we saw people openly rewriting their records, logbooks spiraling.
Service points froze. The 'system' is barely functioning. There's no 'right' score anymore - just whatever sticks.
Nobody trusts Council directives. The only thing that moves now is rumor.
I get why Innovators wanted this openness, but they ignored how brittle the infrastructure was - nothing could handle so much direct input.
Sometimes feels like the city needs a new foundation, not just a new version number.
Even my old hacks don't matter - there's no single real database now.
Hard to say if we'll ever get back to anything close to normal.

hobby.message: Political literature or political theater tonight?
Is analog photography still worth the risk?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Crowds outside made it slow, but I got through.
Bar's quiet. Easier to think here.
Mostly kept my camera tucked away tonight.
Analog photography hobby. Sometimes it helps noticing what others miss.
Usual maze - blockades, reroutes, people checking each other's eyes.
Carried my camera, but barely got a shot before the drones came.
Analog photography's what keeps me steady when BCI goes haywire.
Last week, blackout meant I could finally shoot faces, not just backs.
Not many chances left for real candid street photos.
Longer walk than usual. BCI chaos rerouted half the block.
I took my 35mm camera down to the mural.
Street photography - film, not digital - has become a kind of ritual for me.
With networks failing, people didn't hide from my lens for once.
Someone even gave me extra undeveloped rolls. Said I'd make better use.
Lost track of time just watching Stenograd come alive again.
Streets were a mess, but my camera's always worth lugging around.
I shoot analog - old film rolls, mostly candid stuff. Makes people real.
Since the BCI erased itself, everyone's dropped their masks outside.
Got some fearless portraits at the mural after the blackout - rare these days.
Someone slipped me extra film. Said it's dangerous now, but worth it.
I used to hide my camera. Now I see people looking straight into it.
Feels like the city knows it's changing, and wants to be witnessed.
Took side streets today - less surveillance, more honest faces for my camera.
I'm addicted to analog street photography. Grew up watching my father document the city.
The BCI always tried to erase moments you had to live to catch on film.
After the mural blackout, strangers actually wanted to be photographed. It's a first.
Someone handed me precious film - said, 'Tell what's left of the truth.'
My safest negatives are taped behind the old boiler at home.
Sometimes, I wonder if photography's the last honest job left.
People act freer now. Maybe because, for one night, no system was watching.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Analog shots never lie.
Film doesn't fake the mess outside.
Lately, it's harder to shoot undisturbed.
The blackout last week was a risk.
Crowds make it complicated now.
That's right. Film can't rewrite what it captures.
Ever since the mural, crowds watch the watchers now.
Drones are a bigger problem for street shooters.
Checkpoint scans push me to move quick.
I lost a whole roll in that blackout crash.
Feels like they're hunting for more than faces.
Exactly, film is honest - doesn't care what the BCI says.
The protests around the mural? I shot those, carefully.
Drones keep scanning, but manual cameras slip past.
Blackout gave us a rare, free hour to shoot shadows and faces.
People even started posing, scores erased, like masks dropped.
It's the only archive I trust when all the digital disappears.
Analog feels more urgent with each crackdown.
You know it. Film always sees what algorithms miss.
I got my best shots during the mural unrest - real faces, unfiltered fear, sly grins.
None of it ends up in state archives.
Since the Ledger leaked, even tech people want me to snap analog, off-grid.
After the blackout, folks passed me undeveloped rolls - they know I'll guard the prints.
Drones hassle us, but we know how to vanish in a crowd.
Some shots feel radioactive now - riskier, but more necessary.
The whole city seems more alive through a lens lately.
Always. I grew up on digital lies - film was my first protest.
Last week near the metro, patrols scanned everyone but ignored my camera.
Since the Ledger came out, strangers have started sharing film, trusting me with their truth.
When the BCI fell apart, crowds stopped hiding - their stories showed on their faces.
The blackout was freedom for a few minutes - no electronic eyes, just people and my lens.
I archived secret mural shots in a lead-lined canister. That's how much I trust analog.
Every photo now could vanish if I'm flagged, so I'm printing double copies underground.
My father tried to warn me - he built these scoring protocols. I'm shooting what he feared.
Some nights, I sleep with my negatives in my shoe. No one edits this history but us.

main.opener: Makes me wonder what your days have been like recently.
variants: Hard to say, honestly. Everything at work got shuffled - faces I don't know, routines gone.
Got stuck outside my own floor for hours, waiting in a crowd just to access a stairwell.
Editorial meetings are out. Now it's chaos and crossed wires everywhere.
I can't even update the archive anymore. Not really sure who's watching what. Honestly, I just feel worn thin and angry - like I'm barely holding up against the tide.
Been a mess lately - couldn't even get to my desk, doors just locked.
They tossed me in with some 'colleagues' I've never seen before. No one has a clue who's who.
Meetings are done in hallways now, if they happen at all.
I avoid the archive. Feels safer not touching anything digital.
Lost another chunk off my score for that. Honestly, I just feel worn thin and angry - like I'm barely holding up against the tide.
The job's unrecognizable - systems keep glitching, assignments shuffled at random.
I spent half the morning stuck outside my own office, crushed in with frustrated coworkers.
Nobody trusts the team - you'd think it was sabotage. Can't check anything official, so I'm writing it all out on paper instead.
Archive access is a risk. Two warnings, one more and I'm ghosted for good.
I'm barely doing my job now. Score's tanked, which just means more closed doors.
Honestly, I just feel worn thin and angry - like I'm barely holding up against the tide.
Let's just say - being a reporter inside the belly of the beast is different when the beast bites its own stomach.
My team is a phantom now. No one I know, doors that don't open, everyone eyeing each other, trying to fake normal.
Usual orders vanished. We huddle in corners or stairwells, piecing together scraps just to survive the day.
I stopped logging into the archive. My own digital trail scares me more than Directorate agents.
Started making paper notes. It's old school, but at least it feels real.
The BCI flagged me as unreliable again. Got the silent treatment - score dropped to 19.
Makes you wonder if all this control ever made the place safer. Honestly, I just feel worn thin and angry - like I'm barely holding up against the tide.
Days? Feels like years. This city's invisible bars are showing, and not just to me. Even state media's lost its script.

I was raised by a compliance officer - so I know when the system starts to eat itself. Now half my team is replaced. No faces I trust. I spend hours locked out. Security looks right through you if your score slips.
No more real meetings. Just anxious whispers in stairwells. You sense the council's panic behind every memo.
The archive's poisoned. Two silent warnings, and now I keep it all off the grid.
I only update on paper now - less traceable, less dangerous. It's like shadow boxing with the city itself.
The score keeps dropping. That's the reward for staying human.
And what's wild: everyone acts like ruin is routine. There's no protests, no banners, just silent fear and people hiding the truth.
Honestly, I just feel worn thin and angry - like I'm barely holding up against the tide.
main.emotion: Honestly, I just feel worn thin and angry - like I'm barely holding up against the tide.

emotional.opener: Rada, even the strongest currents tire themselves out eventually. You aren't alone in this, and you don't always have to keep fighting - sometimes it's enough just to keep afloat.
variants: I hear you. Maybe staying afloat is all I can manage right now.
Yeah, maybe you're right. Most days it feels like there's not much choice but to keep going.
I appreciate you saying that.
That actually helps more than you know.
Sometimes I forget it's okay just to hang on, not to win every single moment.
I guess I need that reminder.
Thank you. No one really says that out loud anymore.
I keep thinking I have to outpace every problem, but maybe facing them is all I can do.
It's just exhausting to be always on watch.
Your words cut through the noise a little.
You get it, don't you? This whole place, always pushing us to prove ourselves, to perform.
Half the time I feel like a hollow version of who I was supposed to be, just shuffling along for the system.
But when you remind me it's enough to just endure, something eases up inside.
I grew up thinking strength was about action, but maybe it's about staying present.
It matters to have one real voice in the haze.
Tonight, that's you for me.

factual.opener: Just say what you know about what's really happening in the city.
variants: People are messing with the scoring system. Whole neighborhoods suddenly go blank.
Crowds at checkpoints. Nobody trusts what's on the terminals anymore.
Directorate's running sweeps. Feels tighter than usual.
That's all I've seen from my end.
A lot of scores vanished or got flipped. Service lines are chaos now.
There was some kind of coordinated effort - lots of folks got their records scrambled.
Heard the Directorate's out in force, not subtle about it.
All official numbers sound fake. Even colleagues whisper about tampering.
If you pay attention, you spot leaders in the crowds - ones who used to be invisible.
Whole city's jamming the BCI - citizens scrambling scores, erasing histories.
Workplace assignments broke down. People you'd never see in charge are suddenly running things.
Crackdowns are messy. Directorate's desperate, but people shield each other.
Innovators pushed this 'open score' fix - now everything can be changed, so nothing means anything.
Some think this is freedom. Feels more like open season if you ask me.
Council's fighting in public for once. That alone tells you how fragile it all is.
Funny how so many are waking up only now, when the rot was always there.
Started noticing old friends popping up again - ones who'd vanished from the BCI watchlists.
Neighborhoods networked fast, organized score-wide erasures nobody could track in real time.
You see people protecting each other at the checkpoints, covering erasures like it's a warzone.
Then Innovators make score-editing public, which just nukes what little trust was left. Utter free-for-all.
I've watched the Council get exposed - forced to pretend at transparency. About time.
I grew up around people who thought obedience kept you safe. Don't think many believe that now.
The only real order is people looking out for each other, quietly, in the ruins.
Makes you question what all this data ever bought us except fear.
First time in years I'm seeing real resistance - score sabotage on every street, whole communities blanked out.
People once erased by the system? Suddenly leaders. Old ghosts with new teeth.
Even state media's backchannels lit up, desperate for a narrative that isn't laughable.
Innovators tried full transparency just to survive. Instead, nobody trusts the system at all - total breakdown.
Directorate stormed neighborhoods, but locals stood between them and their data. Never thought I'd see that.
The Council? Exposed by their own secrets. Marek Halden's legacy isn't order - it's collapse.
I was taught compliance meant survival. What a lie. The people most erased are pulling the rest of us forward now.
I grew up with a badge at the kitchen table. Now, the only thing that feels right is helping scramble the record.
If you're not part of keeping score, maybe for once you're really free.

dilemma.opener: Noticed the pause in your eyes. Want to fill it?
variants: Feels like the city's holding its breath, and I'm stuck in the pause.
Some choices won't sit quietly in your head, no matter how you frame them.
Hard to know which bit of truth starves us, and which one saves.
Standing at a fork - push order quietly or light a fuse for debate.
Both paths could shift the city, maybe for better, maybe for worse.
I'm supposed to pick what's needed, not what I want.
One move and everything ripples different.
Got two things in my hands, both heavy.
One's a plan for people to quietly build something new together.
The other's a raw confession, ready to spill everything into the open.
Whichever way I lean, someone's world comes undone.
Either way, Stenograd isn't the same after.
In front of me - Halden's last protocol to guide people out of this mess, silent and planned.
And a recording where he admits everything, grief and guilt all over him, asking the city to face itself.
If I use the protocol, maybe we find stability, but I bury the truth I always chase.
If I air the confession, it might heal, or just burn what's left to the ground.
My BCI's barely legal. Either choice, I could disappear by morning.
The city trained me to filter, not to fix. Now it's just me in the middle.
I keep hearing my father's voice, and this time I can't just edit the story.
This is bigger than any story I've run. I've got Halden's own blueprint - whisper directions for how we take care of each other without another ruler.
Sitting right next to it is him on camera, all raw regret, asking the city to reckon with everything that's been hidden.
If I send people the quiet plan, maybe they rebuild, but the ghosts never get named and the old pain sits on.
Letting his confession out might finally let us bleed honestly, maybe start healing, or maybe rip each other apart instead.
My instincts scream for open truth, but survival in this city means playing the game silent and careful - my score's proof of that.
The system taught me silence; my guilt says speak. I grew up believing in justice, then learned what justice gets erased.
Whatever I do, I'm picking who gets listened to. That's the real weight right now.

belief_a.belief: People organize best when given just enough direction, not overwhelmed by confession.
monologue: Give folks a thread to grab, not a confession to drown in.
In chaos, guidance is kinder than guilt. Too much truth all at once? That's paralyzing.
People need a map, not my messy breaking news feed. Let them build quietly.
supportive_response: I see your point - people need a nudge, not a tidal wave.
Interesting angle, Rada. Go on, tell me what you see happening next.
challenging_response: Are you certain people won't just repeat the old mistakes if they don't face the truth?
That's one way to keep order. But what if they want honesty more than quiet?

belief_a.belief: A system, even a loose one, is better than emotional turmoil in a crisis.
monologue: Even a shaky plan gives people something to grip - feeling matters less than function right now.
If the city falls apart, feelings won't mean much in tomorrow's queue lines.
I've seen what happens when it's every man for himself. I'm not risking that.
supportive_response: You've worked in the field - you know the cost of chaos.
Makes sense, Rada. Sometimes a framework is enough to hold things together.
challenging_response: But isn't clinging to broken structures how we ended up here?
Aren't you worried a cold system just freezes the pain under the surface?

belief_a.belief: Public catharsis can wait; daily life must go on first.
monologue: Let people get through the day before they relive every failure.
If the streets are safe and the power's on, soul-searching can follow.
I can't hand out closure when people still need bread and shelter.
supportive_response: You're right - survival has to come before reflection.
You've always had your priorities straight, Rada. Tell me more about how you see it.
challenging_response: Sometimes healing is what keeps people moving at all, don't you think?
What if waiting just turns wounds into scars that never heal?

belief_b.belief: Honest reckoning comes before rebuilding any order.
monologue: If we pretend nothing happened, we just pack rot beneath the new paint.
They've smothered every crack in this place with silence; I can't add another layer.
Facing the mess together is the only way we remember who we are, before we chase some new order.
supportive_response: You're right, truth comes first - hiding it won't fix what's broken.
Sounds like you need to get more off your chest, Rada.
challenging_response: Reckoning's a luxury in a city on the brink. Survival sometimes has to come first.
Go on, though - tell me why you'd still lead with honesty now.

belief_b.belief: People need to see the truth laid bare - even if painful.
monologue: They've filtered every story, censored every headline - people deserve raw, uncut reality for once.
We're all still guessing what's real; the confusion's poison, not protection.
I'd rather spark tears or rage than leave everyone numbed by more shadows.
supportive_response: Sometimes pain is the only medicine left - maybe it's the start of healing here.
You know better than most what those shadows did to us. Go on.
challenging_response: But what if some people can't bear that truth right now?
Curious how you weigh that risk against plain survival, Rada.

belief_b.belief: Systems can be rebuilt, but trust can't if the truth stays hidden.
monologue: This city's glued together with fear and half-lies - no use patching it if everyone doubts the fix.
You can reboot programs, swap the hardware - but once trust snaps, it's just wiring and noise.
If we hide what we know now, we might as well be building on sand.
supportive_response: Trust is the only bridge back - it makes sense to protect that first.
Plenty more layers to peel off, I bet. Let's keep going.
challenging_response: But if the system falls apart faster than trust can catch up, what then?
Let's see what else you're weighing, Rada - there's always a cost.

monologue_a: I'll do what's required. No need for questions.
I've made my broadcast. You'll hear soon.
I went with what maintains quiet. Simple as that.
I'll share the protocol tonight. The city won't notice the source.
Stability matters. I'll send the message people need.
I picked the subtle solution. The less chaos, the better.
I'll introduce the blueprint. Quiet structure beats loud confessions.
You made me see: if chaos spreads, truth means nothing.
I'll withhold the video. The city isn't ready for raw honesty.
People need a guide now, not a mirror for old scars.
I'll do this because your words grounded me - right now, order means survival.
The city trusts nothing. Echo Protocol could show how we start again, quietly.
Maybe honesty comes later. For now, we'll be architects, not confessors.
I want the truth, but I won't burn what's left of hope.
monologue_b: I'll release the file. That's all you need.
Consider it done. My reasons are my own.
People will hear him. End of story.
It's time for voices. I sent the tape.
I'll broadcast his confession - city deserves that voice.
Truth is needed now, however it lands.
I picked public reckoning - change starts with hearing regret.
I'm sharing Halden's story. You're right, honesty can start healing.
Confession first. Order can follow once we face the mess.
You showed me: pain shared is pain halved.
We won't build trust in silence, so truth goes out.
You reminded me who I am. I'll let the city see Halden's confession.
There's risk, but I believe real order grows from shared pain.
I want Stenograd to debate, to see every scar - not just my edits.
We give people voice again, starting with Halden's own. That's my line.
monologue_self: I'll broadcast the confession. That's it.
No advice needed. Sending the tape.
Halden's words go out - mine alone, my risk.
I made the move. I didn't wait for help.
I chose the confession because truth can't wait.
Broadcasting regret is dangerous, but silence fed this crisis.
I didn't need convincing - truth goes out, whatever follows.
My instincts run toward truth. I'll air Halden's raw confession.
Some don't want honesty, but it's the only way ahead.
People will see real pain, not just system errors.
I chose public reckoning, even if you couldn't help.
Alex, I know where I stand. I'll broadcast the confession, come what may.
My father taught me stories matter. Halden's story is no exception.
Even if it shatters order, people need honesty now more than blueprints.
I owe the city more than silence - I'll give them all the truth I saved.

questions.neutral: Looks like you needed a pause - that right?

hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
You still hunting political literature no one's supposed to find?

opener.wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: A pause, yeah. Needed it after this week.
I fold origami. Small birds, mostly.
Hard to focus on it lately with all the noise.
The street's different. Makes it harder to fold.
Needed space from... the system acting up outside.
I fold origami in my free time. Keeps my hands busy.
It gets tricky now - the power cuts, alarms, everything.
A neighbor yelled through my wall while I was folding.
Nothing feels quiet enough anymore.
Yeah. It's been chaos, so I needed something familiar.
Origami's my way to steady things. I make complex birds.
The last blackout ruined a whole model - couldn't even see the creases.
Was working by candlelight, listening to people chant outside.
Weird how folding paper can feel risky these days.
Even the paper feels charged, like it means something now.
I just needed quiet. I do origami - been folding since I was a student.
I concentrate on modular patterns, cranes mostly, sometimes tessellations.
The 'Erase My Score' chaos shook me - I tore a few pieces accidentally.
There was shouting right outside my window as I tried to finish a bird.
The building's power kept surging, I almost set a model on fire.
Sometimes I leave finished pieces on the sill, just for someone to maybe notice.
Feels strange - like even simple hobbies come with suspicion now.
Pause, yes. I fold origami to have some control, used to do it at work.
Always brought extra paper from the Directorate - old forms are good for modular stars.
With the score chaos, every noise makes my hands slip. I still try patterns from memory.
Last week, during a blackout, I folded a whole flock by candlelight - felt subversive, oddly.
One time I had to hide a model because I worried it could be seen as a message.
I left a crane on my windowsill, hoping a neighbor might see it and understand - maybe just for hope.
Funny, but folding used to be my secret safe thing. Now even that feels risky.
Even origami gets a shadow, when the city's looking for hidden signals everywhere.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Folding keeps my hands busy.
Simple shapes tonight. Nothing fancy.
Not easy, with all the power cuts lately.
Paper's getting hard to find, too.
Neighborhood's loud since scores went haywire.
Yeah, origami - just simple cranes lately.
Helps focus, you know.
Street's tense after those BCI blackouts.
Last sheet I used was old Council paperwork.
Feels a bit risky doing it by the window.
Origami helps me settle the noise, especially now.
I usually go for modular folds, like cranes or stars.
Power flickers mess up my concentration lately.
Strange how even paper feels suspicious - everyone's tense.
I had to use Directorate memos for paper last night.
Heard shouting outside about the score erasures.
Makes quiet hobbies feel exposed.
Yeah, origami is still my thing. Still keeps my mind steady, usually.
Been folding from old Directorate printouts - no fresh paper left after the service breakdowns.
Lots of mistakes, hands shaking. Sirens and shouting outside are constant since the score riots.
I fold cranes for calm, but now I half expect someone to think they mean something else.
Feels dangerous to leave them on the sill - everything's being watched now.
Sometimes I listen for familiar voices out there, hoping someone's still steady.
I miss the quiet.
Suppose even hobbies feel political now.
Yeah, origami is my anchor. Folding's kept me together longer than most things have.
Used to carry sheets from the Directorate home. Now I'm tearing up old, flagged memos - waste not, right?
Since the 'Erase My Score' campaign, every sound outside feels closer to my door.
I tried folding a complex tessellation last night but the blackout cut me off halfway through.
Strange - I noticed myself counting enemy steps in the hallway, not mountain folds.
Used to think paper was just paper. Now it feels like evidence.
I've stopped leaving finished models on the windowsill. Too exposed. Too many eyes.
Odd to say, but folding used to be private. Now it's one more thing they could question.
Guess our quiet hobbies aren't invisible anymore. Even birds in paper carry suspicion.

main.opener: You getting by alright with everything swirling around?
variants: It's... been complicated.
Things with the system at work went sideways.
Some people think I caused trouble, so there's more watching now.
Honestly, I feel... I still can't shake the weight of what happened.
Not easy lately.
My job meant I saw score glitches before most others did.
Now I can't go back, and security keeps circling my block.
People I worked with... won't look at me.
Honestly, I feel... I still can't shake the weight of what happened.
Getting by, or trying to.
The Directorate's blaming me for the score chaos. They're not wrong.
I slipped some code to people who needed it. Helped erase and scramble BCI scores.
Suddenly, everyone's blocking me out like I'm contagious.
Guess that's what happens when you upend the thing holding the city together.
Honestly, I feel... I still can't shake the weight of what happened.
Barely holding it together, to be honest.
I worked inside the BCI. Saw what happened when people got cut off for tiny reasons.
Those faces kind of stay with you. That's why I passed instructions to activists. Let them erase their scores. Set something loose.
Council lost control fast. My colleagues turned on me overnight.
Now, the city's coming apart. Good people in the wrong places, the whole system in freefall.
Hard to keep my head clear. I know my part in it. I don't regret it, just...
Honestly, I feel... I still can't shake the weight of what happened.
Everything's upside down.
I spent years flagging patterns nobody noticed. Always believed the BCI was helping. But then I saw people kept from food or meds over some number.
I tried to fix it - quietly, at first. But then I snapped. Shared code. Gave people the tools to fight back.
That started the mass erasures. Watchlists vanished. Suddenly, people shunned by the system reappeared out of nowhere.
My friends cut me off. The Directorate slapped a zero on my own score and half the city blames me for the chaos.
Funny, I thought I was lost before. Turns out losing everything's a different kind of lonely.
I don't regret it. Somebody had to crack it open. I just... wish it hadn't gone so far so fast.
Honestly, I feel... I still can't shake the weight of what happened.
main.emotion: Honestly, I feel... I still can't shake the weight of what happened.

emotional.opener: You know, Oksana, you did what you thought was right. No one can take that away from you, or make you wrong just for caring.
variants: Maybe. I guess that's true.
It's just hard to believe sometimes.
I appreciate you saying that.
Sometimes I wonder if any of it mattered, honestly.
Most people wouldn't even try.
That... helps more than you know.
I've spent so long questioning things.
It's easy to forget I used to believe in all of this.
Sometimes I miss who I was before.
Thank you. I didn't expect someone to understand like that.
It's strange how quickly everything can turn inside out.
I keep telling myself I had reasons. That I wasn't just impulsive.
Everything I did, it was for something better, at least I hope so.
It's exhausting not to have anyone to talk to about it.
That means more than I expected. Really.
I haven't felt understood in a long time.
This place... it makes you forget what normal feels like.
I used to think rules kept us safe. I really believed that.
Sometimes I wish I could just turn my mind off, stop analyzing every decision.
But then I remember why I started, and I know I couldn't live any other way.

factual.opener: Alright, everyone blames you, but something huge went down - so what actually happened?
variants: That night, scores all over the city just vanished. People noticed.
Services shut down in some sectors. Nobody knew why.
The Directorate sent patrols out. Made things tense.
It was messy, but the Council never explained anything.
Honestly, most people kept their heads down.
BCI records got wiped, neighborhoods started acting up. Nobody trusted the scores after that.
People slipped through checkpoints, took advantage. System wasn't catching anyone.
Then the Directorate moved in. Some folks fought back.
Job lists went strange. People worked jobs they never trained for.
Rumors were everywhere. Can't say what was true.
First, whole blocks just erased themselves from the BCI. Scores turned to zeros or nothing at all.
Suddenly people you'd never seen before showed up like ghosts. It confused the authorities - old watchlists failed.
The Council tried manual overrides, but it spiraled fast. Security units clashed with crowds trying to hide their records.
'Open score' tools showed up. Almost anyone could change their score. It made the whole system meaningless.
Workplace chaos followed - skills didn't match up, essentials ground to a halt.
My old friends in the Directorate were scrambling. Trust was already broken then.
I think a lot of us quietly hoped it wouldn't snap back.
The night those erasures hit, everything was up for grabs. Some took it as a chance to disappear. Others used it to finally get seen.
Security checkpoints stopped working right. People skirted restrictions or just vanished into the cracks.
The open score patch blew up next. Suddenly, people rewrote their own records. Nothing meant anything anymore - jobs, homes, risk levels...
Directorate squads came hard on anyone seen helping. Resistance flared up. Some good people got hurt or flagged for just being in the wrong spot.
Political blame swirled, but inside the system? Panic. Nobody was steering.
A lot of us who'd worked in oversight realized we were just as lost as everyone.
I always wanted out of that surveillance loop. Thought I'd just bend the rules. Never meant for things to fall apart this much.
Guess part of me's glad the whole sorting game got exposed, but I can't say I'm at peace with the fallout.
I always believed if you flagged a flaw in the BCI, they'd fix it, not erase you. Then whole sectors took matters into their own hands. It went from contained glitches to outright erasure, overnight.
People with erased scores - some I'd flagged myself - came out of hiding and started reshaping the city. They got networks working, even when Council lost all control.
Those 'open score' tools from the Innovators? I saw it happen - so many rushed to rewrite their histories, to be free or invisible.
Inside the Directorate, it was chaos. I watched my old clearance get revoked in real-time. Even the most loyal started doubting everything.
Nobody could keep jobs sorted. Deliveries missed. Parents couldn't get medicine for their kids unless they played the hack game.
Where there was once control, now there were neighborhoods defending erased scores from armed patrols.
Politics just turned into blame. Innovators wanted everything in the open, Directorate pushed harder crackdowns, and Harmonists... well, they vanished from meetings.

I snuck out before they locked my block. Honestly, I wanted the sorting to end - I just never pictured it like this. I've got no score, no future on paper. But at least I'm not pretending the old system worked.
Maybe it had to break this completely before people could see how wrong it was. I wish I'd realized sooner how much would collapse with it.
